metadata.title: Water-soluble metal complexes and catalysts Part 6. A new, efficient water-soluble catalyst for two-phase hydroformylation of olefins

A new, efficient water-soluble catalyst for two-phase hydroformylation of olefins Wolfgang A. Herrmann**, Christian W. Kohlpaintner Anorganisch-chemisches Institut O Technischen Universitat Munchen, Lichtenbergstr. 4, D-8046 Garching (Germany) Helmut Bahrmann and Werner Konkol Oxo Research Laboratories, HOECHST AG, Werk Ruhrchemie, D-4200 Oberhausen 11 (Germany) (Received November 22, 1991; accepted January 17, 1992) Ostract The diphosphane 2,2'-bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)-1,1'-biphenyl (1, BISBI) was sulfonated by means of oleum containing 65% S03. The sulfonation product, 2 (BISBIS), was purified by extraction-reextraction techniques. The sodium salts, 3, of BISBIS (2) are accessible as a mixture of several sulfonated derivatives. In the heterogeneous (biphasic) hyarofornnylation of propene, this sulfonated ligand 3 yields exceptionally high n/iso ratios of the resulting butyric aldehyde (rhodium catalysis). High activity and productivity at low phosphane/rhodium ratios are additional advantages of using 3. Hydroformylation of higher olefins, e.g., 1-hexene, is also within the scope of the new catalytic Rh(I)BISBIS system. Introduction The separation of reaction products from a homogeneous hydroformylation catalyst is an unavoidable step in industrial processes. Leaching of the catalyst and thermal decomposition lead to normally unacceptable losses in activity and productivity. Immobilization of the catalyst is therefore an economic necessity. Various pathways with which to beat this challenge have recently been reported [2, 3], with water-soluble catalysts now being the prevailing theme [4]. In our ongoing work on hydroformylation [5] we became interested in water-soluble phosphanes as ligands for rhodium-containing catalysts in two-phase systems. It is well known that chelating diphosphanes improve the n/iso ratio of products in the hydroformylation of olefins. The diphosphane 2,2'bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)-1,1'-biphenyl (1, BISBI) was reported to yield *Communication no. 5 of this series: see reference [ 11. "Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$5.00 0 1992 - Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved 192 excellent linear-to-branched product selectivity [6]. Beyond the well-known TPPTS (tris(m-sodiumsulfonatophenyl)phosphane) used in the industrial hydroformylation of propene [ 7 ], water-soluble chelating diphosphanes should prove economically beneficial for this process. Furthermore, a more reliable assessment of medium-size chelate ring ligands in catalysis is to be expected. In the present paper we report on a simple NMR technique for optimizing sulfonation of ligand precursors, and on the preparation and purification of the new water-soluble ligand BISBIS (2). Results of hydroformylation of propene and 1-hexene with the new Rh(I)BISBIS catalyst are also reported. Results SuVOtion The ligand BISBI was prepared by a new synthetic route developed in our laboratory [8]. Alternative routes have been described in several recent patents granted to Eastman Kodak [9]. Sulfonation of the diphosphane 1 with concentrated sulfuric acid containing various amounts of S03 (i.e., oleum) to yield 2 was optimized with in situ NMR techniques. With this method, depicted in Fig. 1, the recording of 31P NMR spectra in oleum solutions became possible. Workup procedures to observe the progress of sulfonation were not necessary. The optimum sulfonation conditions with respect to reaction time, S03 content, and side products (phosphane oxides) are listed in Table 1. The preferred reaction conditions were found to be 6590 oleum and a reaction time of 17 h at room temperature. Higher temperatures or prolonged contact time led to increasing amounts of phosphane oxides. The extent to which the latter were formed did not depend strongly on the S03 content, H3P04 Wig. 1. NMR tube with two inlet tubes for an situ spectroscopy. 193 TABLE 1 Results of sulfonation with respect to phosphane oxides' [S03] (96) Reaction time (h) 20 42 12 20 72 14 20 818 15 40 42 34 65 17 10 65 72 100 'All experiments carried out at room temperature. bDetermined by prior standardization with completely oxidized BISBIS. Oxides (96) HS03 Na*S03 I~ P(CsHs)z Oleum I / PPh,(CgH4SO3H)z, I , PArz_ Ph P(CsHs)z \ ~ PPh (C6H4SOzH)z_r, ~ ~ ~PArz_^ HS03 Na*S03' 1 2 3 ("BISBI") C31SBISI ("BISBIS-Na") Equation 1. Synthesis of BISBIS--Na (3). Ar=CBHq-m-S03-Na+; n=0, 1. at least at short reaction times. The unexpected observation that alkyldiarylphosphanes are relatively stable toward oxidation during the sulfonation process [10] was seen once again in this particular case. Synthesis of compound 2 was recently claimed in patents [9a, c], but convincing characterization is missing. In addition, the route according to which 2 was said to be formed seems chemically infeasible. The synthesis described in our present paper proves the existence of 2 (and 3) for the first time. The synthesis of the sodium salts 3 of the desired sulfonated diphosphane 2 can be conveniently carried out in 100-g amounts. The solubility of this product is approximately 1500 g 1- i in water. In a typical batch of 3 (see experimental section), 95% contain four or more (up to six) SOa-Na+ groups. Separation The reaction mixture was worked up according to a method described in the patent literature [ 11 ]. After careful hydrolysis at ice temperature, the strongly acidic solution was extracted into tris(isooctyl)amine dissolved in toluene. The resulting quaternary ammonium salt of the sulfonated phosphane could thus be extracted into the organic phase. After separation of the aqueous phase, the phosphane was reextracted under pH control by means of a NaOH solution (see experimental section). This procedure prevents 194 formation of the huge amounts of Na2S04 that normally occur during the conventional workup [ 12 ]. The resulting sulfonation product, `BISBIS-Na' (3), was used without further purification in the hydroformylation experiments with propene and 1-hexene. Catalysis The apparatus for the catalytic tests was appropriate for continuous hydroformylation (see Fig. 2). This equipment allows one to vary reaction conditions very easily and to investigate the dependence of the catalytic system on parameters such as temperature, pressure, and amount of olefin. PropO hydroformylation The new BISBIS-rhodium catalyst was first investigated with regard to catalytic activity. To this end, the system was tested in the hydroformylation of propene, with a phosphorus-rhodium ratio (P/Rh) of only 6.7:1 instead of the 80:1 typical of the analogous TPPTS-rhodium system. The results are shown in Table 2 and in Fig. 3. The activity and the productivity could be raised to values of greater than 90 and 1.1, respectively. When the amount of propene was increased to more than 125 g h-1, activity and productivity decreased dramatically. Decreasing the propene flow afterward, the catalyst activity could be reestablished at a high value. The n/iso ratio of C4-aldehydes varied during these syngas exhaust gas propene catalyst circuit product by-pass Fig. 2. Apparatus for continuous hydroformylation. Filters, pressure gauges, valves, and pumps have been omitted for clarity. Hydroformylation of propene: dependence of activity on the amount of propene. experiments over only a small range (95:5 to 97:3). With higher activity, the building rate of alcohols (n-butanol and isobutanol) decreased from an initial 9.5% to 1.37% at the end. The production of condensation products such as 2-ethylhexanol was negligible. During these tests, the organic product was examined in terms of phosphorus and rhodium compounds; only 0.7 ppm phosphorus(IIn and 0.112 ppm rhodium were detected. In order to compare the new rhodium-BISBIS system with the welllalown rhodium-TPPTS catalyst, hydroformylation of propene was carried out under the same reaction conditions. The results are given in entry 11 in Table 3. Activity and productivity (45.5 and 0.59) were three times higher compared with TPPTS (15 and 0.2, respectively), although the P/fth ratio was twelve times smaller. The n/iso ratio also improved, from 94:6 (TPPTS) to nearly 97:3 (BISBIS). Notably, building rates of alcohols (6.7'0) and condensation products (1.5%) were higher. The behaviour of the rhodium-BISBIS system was also studied for pressure and temperature dependence. The admission pressure of syngas (CO/HZ) was lowered from 725 psi. As shown in Table 3, the activity decreased at a pressure of 180 psi. The dependence of catalyst activity on syngas admission pressure is shown in Fig. 4. A further set of experiments was carried out at constant pressure (725 psi) and various temperatures; lower activity/productivity occurred at lower temperatures (Table 4). Even at 116 C, the rhodium-BISBIS system showed higher activity than a comparable TPPTS system. From an Arrheruus plot the apparent activation energy was calculated to be 17 kcal mol -1. This small value corresponds to the calculated activation energy for a homogeneous hydroformylation catalyst [ 15 ] and a supported aqueous-phase catalyst with TPPTS [16]. 1-Hexene hydroformylation The hydroformylation of higher olefins in two-phase systems suffers from low activities due to the poor solubility of long-chain alkenes in water. We used 1-hexene as an example of a higher olefin. ','See Table 2. (T=123 C, p = 725 psi), conversion of the olefin was low but improved with higher temperatures (Table 5). The activity increased from 0.73 to 10.73 when the temperature was raised from 123 to 155 C, whereas the n/iso ratio decreased from 97:3 to 94:6. Entry 24 in Table 5 concerns the catalyst stability after 16 h of continuous hydroformylation; even at this higher temperature, no deactivation was observed. Discussion The new water-soluble diphosphane, 3, yields outstanding results when employed as a ligand in the rhodium-catalyzed hydroformylation of propene, particularly in view of the low ligand-to-rhodium ratio of only 7:1. It is not usually appreciated that industrial processes depend on large amounts of phosphanes to be used for sufficiently long operating times of catalysts, the ligand-to-rhodium ratios normally being 100:1 to 1000:1 in hydroformylation. 199 The reasons for the special effectiveness of 3 are not yet obvious. A study concerning the influence of diphosphanes of type Ph2P-(CH2),-PPh2 on the hydroformylation activity [ 13 ] showed that especially for n =1 and n = 6, the effects of high conversion rates are small in comparison to those for n = 2, 3, and 4. In contrast, 3 (n = 6) shows very high activities. This may be due to electronic effects and the more rigid structure of 3 compared with these alkyl-chained diphosphanes. The precursor 1 was shown to adapt to steric requirements of the metal(s) in a very flexible way (molecular modelling, crystal structures) [ 14 ]. Both the cis- and trans-configuration extremes are possible. At the same time, the bidentate nature of 1 (and 2 / 3) prevents the ligand from departing from the metal. The medium-size ring system (nine atoms) does not put significant steric and kinetic constraints upon the intermediates that operate in hydroformylation. Further work along these lines is in progress. Experimental General procedures 31P{1H} NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL JMN-GX 400 spectrometer (20 C, 161.8 MHz referenced to external conc. H3P04). Air-sensitive materials were manipulated in an inert atmosphere using Schlenk techniques. Solvents were dried in the usual way. The diphosphane 1 was synthesized according to the method in ref. [8]. Sulfonation NMR experiments 500 mg (0.91 mmol) of 2,2'-bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)-l, I'-biphenyl (1) were dissolved in concentrated sulfuric acid. At ice temperature, 5 ml of oleum (various amounts of S03) were dropped slowly into the solution. After the solution warmed up to the ambient temperature, the reaction conditions were adjusted for the different samples. In connection with the sulfonation reaction, the resulting solutions were characterized in situ by 31p NMR and investigated with respect to degree of sulfonation and the extent of phosphane oxide formation. Synthesis scale 12 g (21.8 mmol) of 2,2'-bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)-1,1'-biphenyl (1) were dissolved in 10 ml of concentrated H2S04. After all of the phosphane was dissolved, 120 ml of oleum (containing 65% S03) were dropped slowly into this solution, while the temperature was maintained in the range 0-5 C. After completion, the slurry was allowed to warm up to the ambient temperature and was stirred for 17 h. The mixture was hydrolyzed under careful temperature control (max. 5 C) by pouring the solution dropwise 200 onto 200 g of ice. The resulting brown solution was further purified by the extraction-reextraction technique. Extractionrreextraction In a 1000-m1 three-neck flask, fitted with a KPG stirrer, burette, and pH electrode, the strong acidic sulfonation mixture was added to 200 ml of toluene and 46.24 g (130 mmol) of tris(isooctyl)amine. The brown aqueous solution faded immediately, while the organic phase turned amber. In some cases, this extraction occurred only after the pH was increased with 509'0 NaOH. After the water phase was separated, 100 ml of pure water were added to the organic mixture and vigorously stirred during the addition of a 5096 NaOH solution via the burette. Under strict temperature control (mar. 25 C), different fractions were isolated corresponding to the derivative pH function. The product-containing aqueous solutions were removed, and for the next fraction, 100 ml of pure water were added again to the organic phase in the flask. This procedure was repeated until a pH of nearly 7 was reached. As expected, in the pH neutral region, the product was reextracted completely into the aqueous phase. The fractions were collected and evaporated in vO, and the residue was examined with respect to Na2S04 amount by Guinier films, which indicated no detectable amounts of Na2S04. Based on elemental analysis, the P/S ratio is 2:5.2. HPLC analysis showed small amounts of phosphane oxides (< 596) and a mixture of six-, five-, and fourfold sulfonated BISBIS (ratio 1.8:4.3:1; retention times 1.37, 2.09, and 2.44 min). 3'P NMR: a = - 6.53 (s), - 7.21 (s), - 9.42 (s), - 9.94 (s) ppm. The solid was used without further purification for the catalytic tests. Hydroformylation experiments 6.9 g of `BISBIS-Na' (3) were dissolved in 30 ml of water. Elemental analysis of phosphorus(IU) compounds indicated 0.281 moles of P(III) per kg solution. 17 ml of this solution, corresponding to 5.89 mmol P(III), were inserted into a stainless-steel reactor with a volume of 150 ml. 4.64 ml (0.883 mmol) of a rhodium(III)-acetate solution (19.6 g Rh 1-1) and 275 ml water were added. A P/Rh ratio of 6.7:1 was obtained. The apparatus was constructed for continuous hydroformylation. The product/catalyst separation occurred in a phase separator, the catalyst solution being pumped and recycled throughout the experiments. Therefore the total volume of originally used catalyst solution (297 ml) is greater than the reaction vessel volume (150 ml). The propene was liquefied at - 7 C/225 psi and was continuously pumped into the vessel. 1-Hexene was used as a liquid. The olefin flow was controlled by decreases in the weight of the stock bin. Every thirty minutes the product was taken from the phase separator and weighed. GC analysis was used to determine yields of aldehyde, the n/iso ratio, and amounts of byproducts. Unreacted and undissolved propene was removed with the exhaust gas. The pH was measured in a bypass of the catalyst circuit. Increasing pH values were counterbalanced by addition of dilute sulfuric acid. 201 Acknowledgements Professor Comils, Dr. Kandler, and Dr. Kottmann of HOECHST AG are acknowledged for their continued support of this work; Dr. Frohning of HOECHST AG, Werk Ruhrchemie, for stimulating discussions. coredata.dc:description: The diphosphane 2,2′-bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl (1, BISBI) was sulfonated by means of oleum containing 65% SO3. The sulfonation product, 2 (BISBIS), was purified by extraction-reextraction techniques. The sodium salts, 3, of BISBIS (2) are accessible as a mixture of several sulfonated derivatives. In the heterogeneous (biphasic) hydroformylation of propene, this sulfonated ligand 3 yields exceptionally high n/iso ratios of the resulting butyric aldehyde (rhodium catalysis). High activity and productivity at low phosphane/rhodium ratios are additional advantages of using 3. Hydroformylation of higher olefins, e.g., 1-hexene, is also within the scope of the new catalytic Rh(I)/BISBIS system.
coredata.dc:title: Water-soluble metal complexes and catalysts Part 6. A new, efficient water-soluble catalyst for two-phase hydroformylation of olefins
